cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. EN ROUTE AGAIN. RODJESTYÈNSKY SCORES. RUSSIANS SANGUINE.

div.p: It is reported that the Russians left the coast of Annam yesterday. (Reuter.)
The Baltic Fleet is still in Kamaranh Bay. Admiral de Jonquieres has taken all measures for ensuring French neutrality. (Reuter)
The consensus , of opinion here is that Rodjestvensky has gained a great advantage through having coaled, and reprovisioned in Kamaranh Bay. (Reuter )
Naval circles hero are sanguine of a coming success. (Reuter.)
The Governor has again proclaimed the prohibition as regards exporting coal except in bunkers. (Reuter.)
The German steamer "Juliette" was not allowed to finish coaling when it was ascertained that she was carrying stores to Kamaranh. (Reuter.)

The Administry, having represented to Rodjcstvetisky that his stay in the proximity of the Annam, coast- is gravely endangering the peace, believes that he will obey the formal instructions already sent him. (Reuter.)
The "Daily Telegraph" learns from Tokio that Japan has Addressed a formal protest to France with reference to the stay of the Russian Fleet in Kamaranh Bay. (Reuter.)

The Japanese Minister here has called the attention of M. Delcassé to tho presence of the Russian ships at Kamaranh. It is maintained, on behalf of France, that she has taken precisely the same measures as when the Japanese cruisers lately visited Kamaranh. Moreover, it is affirmed that the Baltic Fleet has quitted the territorial waters. (Reuter )
Japan has protested to the French Government against her breach of neutrality in favor of the Russian squadron. The latter left Kamaranh Bay several days ago. (Havas.) ,

It is semi officially announced that the Japanese representative principally desired to obtain formal assurance from France that she would continue to strictly observe her neutrality, just as she did when Rodjestvensky passed Cherbourg, and when be was stationed in the vicinity of Madagascar. Special instructions have been sent to Indo-China and M. Delcassé was, therefore, able to calm the Japanese anxiety, for which hitherto there has been no justification. The Government as regards Indochina' has adopted, in connection with the Russians, the same measures as those recently taken when the Japanese cruisers visited Kamaranh. ( Ratter.)
The Japanese resentment against France is growing. It is manifesting itself in the shape of public meetings which pass heated resolutions. A great popular demonstration is proposed. (Reuter.)

It is stated here that France has addressed a communication to Sr. Petersburg, and renewed its orders to the authorities in Indo-China to insist upon the Russians observing French neutrality. (Reuter.)

M. Rouvier, in the Chamber, emphatically reaffirmed that formal, precise, and repeated orders have been sent to the French officials in Indo-China, in order to maintain absolute neutrality in those waters. (Reuter)
(Evening). In view of the negotiations with France, the political leaders are counseling the newspapers to be more moderate. (R.)
The activity of the China squadron is noticeable. H.M.S. cruiser "Hogue" has been ordered to be in readiness for sea with full steam on 2 hours notice. (Reuter.)

Orders have been given to dismantle the Raman ship "Diana," which is undergoing important repairs in a coast port. The main party of the machinery will be handed over to the French authorities. (Havas)

div.head: THE FRENCH CHAMBER THE NEUTRALITY QUESTION GERMANY AND MOROCCO M. DELCASSE RESIGNS

div.p: Parliament has definitely passed Budget for the year 1905. The Senate has adjourned till the 23rd May. In the Chamber the Government declared itself ready to give Germany reassuring explanations regarding its interests in Moreocco. Replying to a question, M. Heavier stated that we would strictly respect our neutrality. Rigorous orders bad been given on tho subject to the authorities in Indo-China. In consequence of some harsh criticism by several speakers on the subject of Morocco, M. Delcasse expressed hit intention of resigning, but it is believed he will retract (Havas.)

M.Delcassé has resigned. His position was shaken at the debate on Wednesday. His adversaries contended that the Emperor William would have never intervened had M. Delcassé considered German susceptibilities. (Reuter.)
The Japanese have occupied Tung-Hua, which is situated 50 miles to the east of Shing-Kiug. The Russians retreated north. (Reuter.)

The Russian scouts have, discovered two strong Japanese columns of cavalry and artillery carrying out an important turning movement to the north-west of Chang-Chung, which is Linievitch's main western position. The Japanese force included 22 guns, a large number of baggage carts and 3,000 Chunchuses, (Reuter.)
The "Bourse Gazette" announces that the Government has decided to utilize the funds of the various public institutions for war purposes, allowing 2% interest of the same. (R.)

The "Morning Post" learns from Shanghai that the Russian cruiser "Askold" is taking in coal. Her breechblocks and machinery, all of which bad previously been removed, have now been duplicated. She is, apparently, preparing for the sea. (Reuter)

Two thousand strikers at the Putiloff workshops, who were preventing their comrades from resuming work, received the mounted police with showers of iron missiles. They were finally dispersed by the infantry. A whole regiment is now quartered in the works, and the vicinity is strongly patrolled. (R.)

The Governors of the Provinces have been informed that the Congress of the members of the Zemstvos fixed for the 7th May hero has been prohibited. They have been ordered to prevent the departure of the delegates. (R.)

In opening the Cretan Chamber, Prince George recalled his own efforts to secure the union of the Island with Greece but condemned the insurrection. He left the Chamber immediately after his speech. The Chamber unanimously proclaimed tee union of Crete with Greece, at the same time expressing confidence in the Prince. The Deputies swore allegiance to the King. Prince George then informed the Consuls. (R.)
The Chamber of Representatives has unanimously passed a vote in favor of the union of the island with Greece. (Havas)
The King and Queen of England are still prolonging their visit here. They have received an immense welcome everywhere, which is regarded as strengthening the "entente cordiale." (Reuter.)
The Italian Chamber has passed the Rail way Bill, including the clause which led to the strike. (Reuter.)
The railway men have abandoned the strike. (Reuter.)

div.head: The Brindisi Mail
div.p: will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8:30 a.m. to-morrow.

div.head: San Stefano-Casino,
div.p: which opened for the season of the 15th inst, already contains a number of guests.

div.head: H.M.S. "Barfleur"
div.p: arrived at Sues yesterday morning from Colombo, and entered the Canal at 10.30 am. bound to Malta.

div.head: Alhambra Theater.—
div.p: The Magnani operetta company is exported to arrive at Alexandria shortly and will make its debut at this theatre.

div.head: Popular University—
div.p: A lecture will be given (in French) on Wednesday next at 9.15 p.m. by M. F. Bourgeois on "Economical Houses and Garden Cities." Admission free.

div.head: Mail Delayed. —
div.p: Owing to the railway strike in Italy, the Florio-Rabattino S.S. "Tebe" left Messina ten hours behind time and will not therefore reach Alexandria till to-mor-row evening.

div.head: To Camel Dealers.—
div.p: There is an enquiry the market for 500 camels for transport and riding purposes. The enquiry comes by cable from Europe, and the tender requires the camels to be delivered at Suez.

div.head: Lord Cromer's Report.—
div.p: Mr. Diemer, the Cairo bookseller, informs us that copies of Lord Cromer's Report may be had at his store. Persons who wish to secure copies are requested to call immediately, as the report is likely to be out of print soon.

div.head: Gatti's Circus Troupe-
div.p: will give matinée performances at the Alhambra tomorrow and Easter Monday, besides the usual evening performances. Tho "Human Arrow," the latest sensation, will take part in the programme

div.head: Death' Sentence.—
div.p: H.H. the Khedive his Approved the sentence of death passed by the Alexandria Native Tribunal on Danik Bas-siourmi, for the murder, on November 25 last, of Mohamed Sakr el Ansari at Nahiet Mellaha Daoud (Bebera).

div.head: The Congo pigmies
div.p: are still in Kasr-el-Ainy Hopital, whore they will remain till their health shows some signs of improvement. The British authorities will decide whether they shall leave the country for Europe when they have completely recovered.

div.head: British Chamber or Commerce. —
div.p: The Chamber's journal for April is not distinguished by any original matter, containing only the Note oh the Assouan Dam and extracts from the Railway Commission's report, besides a translation of the cotton worm decree.

div.head: Suez Canal.—
div.p: 31 vessels passed though the Cans) on the 18th and 19th inst Of these 18 British; 5 German, 2 Austrian, 2 Dutch, 1 Danish, 2 French, 1 Turkish. The reoeipts for the two days were frs 909,496.97, making the total from the 1st inst frs. 6,475,529 59.

div.head: Successful Alexandrian Student.—
div.p: The spring term of the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, closed yesterday week, when the principal (the Rev. J.B. McClellan) conferred the awards on the successful students. The chief awards included :—Scholarship : £25, Albert Sassoon, Alexandria, Egypt.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society.—
div.p: A meeting of the society will be held at the School of Medicine, Kasr-el-Ainy, on Monday, 24th inst., at 4.30 p.m., for the election of a president and secretary. At 6 o'clock Professor Looss will give a lantern demonstration of the wanderings of the Ankylostoma worm in the body.

div.head: Mohamed Aly Centenary—
div.p: An executive committee has been elected under the presidency of Idris Bey Ragheb to organize the fetes that will take place on the 18th May. It has been decided to give a river fete on the Nile between Kisf el-Nil and Ghizeh on the night of the 13th May and illuminate the Opera Square, Place Mohamed Ali, and the Rue do la Poste.

div.head: The Capitulations. —
div.p: In another column will be found a translation from an interesting article on the Capitulations from the native point of view. "Al Lews" very forcibly shows the danger to the public interests that must continually be felt so long as the Capitulations remain in force, and states with great moderation the injustice at present suffered in many cases by the native population of Egypt.

div.head: Prince Colibri.—
div.p: "Great Peter the Small' is about to quit us for good, bing bound to depart from Alexandria on Wednesday next. He leaves behind him a host of needy made friends and well-wishers in his futon career in London, where be is engaged to appear towards the latter end of May. To-morrow, Monday, and Tuesday are the last days on which be exhibits in his "boudoir" next the Alhambra Theatre.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL
div.p: Open all the year round,

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY. THE LIQUIDATION.
div.p: According to telegrams received from Paris, the negotiations in progress for the liquidation of the Daira Sanieh by the aid of the Crédit Foncier Egyptian have been brought to a successful issue. This establishment will take over the liabilities of purchasers of Daira lands, extending the annuities where possible from 15 to 50 years, or even longer periods. The sum required for this operation is reckoned at about eight millions sterling, and it is said that it has been guaranteed by Sir Ernest Casual at a rate equal to about 3 3/4%. As the rate of interest on the annuities is to be 5 1/2%, the difference between 3 3/4% and 5 1/2% on eight millions will remain as profit to be divided between the Crédit Fonder and the Daira Sanieh Company. Holders of the latter shares will receive the liquidation values in cash half in October, 1906, and half in April, 1906.

div.head: ANOTHER EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: Another Egyptian company in the nature of a business trust and mortgage company is shortly to be floated in Egypt and London with a capital of about a quarter pf a million. The board of directors a number of well-known English business men.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST & INVESTMENT.
div.p: We are authorized to state that the second batch of allotments letter and regrets for Alexandria of the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Ltd., were posted by the company to the parties interested the first thing this morning A notice was posted at the Bourse yesterday inviting holders of allotment letters bearing the numbers 501 to 1,000 to present their receipts at the company's offices, 6, rue de l'ancienne Bourse, this day between the boars of 9 and 12 am in order to receive payment for the excess amount paid by them on application.

div.head: NEW STEAMSHIP LINE.
div.p: A new steamship company has boon formed to acquire a shipping concern established in Egypt and to develop its present business, by starting new lines in the Red Sea and also to the Pine us and Constantinople, with fast and luxurious steamers. The flotation will take place shortly and the services will be started immediately afterwards. The board of directors comprises some of our best-known Alexandrians, and the new venture promise to be a great success. We will publish farther details in a few days.

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS CO.
div.p: We beg to draw the attention of our readers the announcement on tho sixth. page of today's issue of the Upper Egypt Hotels Company, limited. The names of the directors are a guarantee of the sound lines on which the company will be run, for it is obvious that it would be impossible to find men who are better acquainted with the business than Messrs. Harrison, Baehler, Nnngovich, and Pagnon.

div.head: NEW DIRECTOR OF SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: Mr. John W. Hughes, a member of the Liverpool shipowning firm of Messrs T. and J. Harrison, has been invited to accept—and, it is understood, has accepted—a seat on the Board of the Suez Canal Company. Mr. Hughes is one of the senior members of the firm of Messrs.' T. and J. Harrison, chairman of the Works Committee of the Mersey Docks and Harbour Board, and a director of the Pacific Steam Navigation Company.

div.head: CAIRO BRITISH RECREATION CLUB.
div.p: With reference to the news which we lately published, to the effect that the club had received notice to hand back their ground to the Government in 6 months' time, we are now informed that the Government has been good enough to give another piece of ground for the use of the club. The new site is situated near the present club ground, on the other side of the canal, to the right of Boulac-road, after crossing the bridge near the Cairo waterworks.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Westcott S.S. "Perim" sailed from Malta on Thursday evening and is due here next Monday with cargo. The Hllerman S.S. "Athenian" arrived at Liverpool on the 17th inst. The S.S. "Menes" arrived at Liverpool on Thursday afternoon. The S.S. "Amasis" sailed on Thursday afternoon for Liverpool via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 1,117 bales cotton. The Moss liner "Rameses" arrived at Malta yesterday morning homeward bound.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the Central position. Under English management

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: LORD MILNER IN EGYPT.
div.p: VISIT TO CAIRO.
(From our Corespondent).
Suez, Friday.

Lord Milner is expected to arrive at Seuz tomorrow afternoon at about 2 o'oclock by the Austrian Lloyd steamer "Koerber" from South Africa. His lordship, after landing at this port, will proceed to Cairo, where he will remain for several days at the British Agency.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: At 10.30 am. to-day Count Bolesta de Kodiebrodski, the new Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent, was received in audience at Abdeen by H. H. the Khedive, to whom be presented his credentials. A guard of honor gave the usual salute at the entrance. Friendly speeches were exchanged, both the Khedive and the Austro-Hungarian Agent emphasizing the excellent relations that have always subsisted between Egypt and the Dual Monarchy.

div.head: THE LATE MAITRE ALBRECHT.
div.p: We understand that the Government have offered Madame Albrecht the handsome sum of £10,000—which we believe Madame Albrecht has been advised not to accept—as compensation for the loss of her husband. Under the Austrian law, where there are minors interested, as in this case, the widow is obliged to leave the decision of acceptance or otherwise in a matter of this sort to the recognized Austrian legal authority, who in this case is the Austrian Representative in Egypt

div.head: YOUNG TURK WANTED.
div.p: The Constantinople Parquet has issued a warrant for the arrest of a Young Turk by name Echref, who is accused of som crimes, and who has fled to Egypt, where has been publishing seditious prints. The local police authorities have recieved orders to effect his arrest.

div.head: BANDMANN OPERA COMPANY.
div.p: Port Said, Friday.

The Bandmann opera company were unable to give a performance of "A Country Girl" at the Eldorado Theatre last night, as advertised, owing to the S.S. "Sumatra'' not arriving till 4 o'clock this morning. They will perform, however, on their way beck from Cairo,of the 2nd May, and seats booked for last night will hold good for that day. Those who have taken tickets and will not be able to attend, can have their money refunded on application at the Eldorado Theatre.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, CAIRO.
div.p: On Sunday next (Easter Day) the services will be as under :- Holy Communion 6.80 am., 7.30 am., 8.30 am., and after morning service. Morning Service 10.30 am. Evening Service 6 p.m.

div.head: ST. MARK'S CHURCH, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 7 a.m. Holy Communion. 8 a.m. Holy Communion. 11 a.m. Matins, Sermon, and Choral Celebration of Holy Communion. The Te Deum Jubilute, Kyrie Eleison, Nicene Creed, Santus and Gloria in Excelsis, in F by Berthold Tours. Tho anthem will be "Why seek ye the living among the dead," by E. J. Hopkins. 6.15 Even song and Sermon. Magnificat and Nunc in F by Berthold Tours. The anthem will he repeated.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, RAMLEH.
div.p: 7.30 a.m. Holy Communion. 8.80 u.m. Holy Communion. 11 a.m. Matins, Sermon, and Holy Communion. 3.30 p.m. Children's service. 6.30 p.m. Evensong and Sermon.

div.head: ROMAN CATHOLIC SERVICES.
div.p: A solemn high mass, which will be attended by M. de la Boulinitre, French Diplomatic Agent, and the personnel of the Agency and Consulate, will be held at 10 a.m. at the Roman Catholic Cathedral at the Monsky, Cairo. A similar mass will be celebrated at St Catherine's Cathedral, Alexandria, M. P. Girard, French Consul, and the consular staff being present.

div.head: M NICOLAOU'S CONCERT.
div.p: M. Constantin Nicolason gave a very successful concert at the Grand Continental Hotel on Wednesday evening. The great heat had naturally some effect on the attendance, but the artist was in great form, and those who heard him enjoyed a great treat To show M. Nicolson's versatility we may say that he gave us songs, many of them with extremely difficult and taxing airs, from eight different composers, all or Dearly all of them operatic. M. Nicolason was most successful, as we thought, in the "Aria del Fishio," from Boito Mefistofele. and in the drinking song from Bizet's Fair Maid of PeriX. He sang with exceptional taste and charm and never pushed his voice, a very pleasant "basse chantante," in attempting to gain effect.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly, whose arrival at Constantinople this week we announced, presented H.I.M. the Sultan with a collection of rare birds which he took with him. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim came down yesterday from Cairo. Abani Pasha, Minister of War, returned to Cairo yesterday. Count Gonzaga Arrivabene, secretary of the Italian Diplomatic Agency, left for Europe on Thursday on leave. Socrates Spiro Bey, of tip Ports and Lighthouses Administration, left for Italy on leave on Thursday. Mohamed Eff. Zeky, interpreter to the Wakfs Administration at Alexandria, has been transferred to Ghizeh. Mr. L B. Schlesinger, of Messrs. A. Keyser and Co., has been elected chairman of the National Electric Construction Company. He is already a director of that company and of the Aboukir Company. '

div.head: PASSENGER LIST
div.p: Arrivals.
Per P. & O. "Sumatra" arrived yesterday horn London and Malta :—

Mr. M. Bandmann, Mist Forsythe, Misa G. Cotisas, Misé N. Pemberton, Mist & French, Miss A. Hill, Mrs. Hamilton, Mr. H. S. Cotter, Mr. W. J. Baker/ Mr. D. Perdrai, Mr. J. Williams, Mr. H. Tillet, Mr. Trimminatam, Miss M. Elba, Miss Katkeek, Miss M. Leslie, Miss N. Leslie, Miss D. Caird, Mias'' Probyn, Misa F. Troaaeder, Mr. and Mrs. Lester, Mr. and Mrs. D. B. O'Connor, Mr. R. Roberta, Mr. F. Vincent, Mr. D. Monro, Mr. S. Lopes, Miss . M. Quest, Mist N. Hoyden.
DEPARTURES.
Per S.S. "Amasis" tailed on Thursday for Liverpool :—
Private Googh, Mr.and Mrs. Oran, Mr. Johnstone, aqÿ 2 deck passengers.
Le paquebot "Singapore'' de la Cie Plorio Rubattino parti jeudi poor Gènes avait h bord :

MM. le lient. Stella, Dr R. firowen, P. Rade-maker, Dr et MmeCano, Comte Arrirabene, C. Pelts, Viale, Dr Pariveni, G. Mmaletti, lieutenants Corso, Rossi et Znnipetta, chev. Peeta-lotza, Major Martinelli, maréchal Mantino, Major P. Spazziaai, V. Beiisario, P. Esposito et fam., Mme. Alby, M. et Mme J. Craggy Mlle Sisley, Christomanos, M. et Mme Piper, Mme. Gibara, Lynn, cap. Dalbertis, M. et Mme L. Galvin, AIL Stagni, Smar Maria, Sœur M. Angelica, Arnaboldi, Mme Pérora et 2 fils, Comt. Merlo, Mlle E. Canepa, cap. Saviano, cap. Minasi, G. Chiappella, Socrate 8piro Boy, Mme. Maorin, Mlle sala Edvige, Emilie Musse, Trille Aman tini, et 95 passagers de 3me classe.

div.head: A.S.C. GOLF.
div.p: The Golf Steward begs to remind members that the entries for Lbs golf meeting dose at 12 noon to-morrow, 23rd inst. So far many members who play golf constantly have not entered for any event. The Golf Steward points out that the system of allowing the full handicap greatly increases the chances of the ordinary or indifferent player, whilst correspondingly minimizing those of the "scratch" man. He hopes therefore that any long handicap players who are hesitating about entering will now take the earliest opportunity of sending in their names for some events. Aboukir Company.—Th e profit and lorn account for 1904 shows a credit balance of £23,049, which added to £2,780 brought forward from the preceding year makes £25,829. The arrears of dividend due on the ordinary shares to December 31,1903, amounting to 10s 10 3/4. per share, were paid in January last, and it is now proposed to declare dividends for the past year of 7 per cent on both the Ordinary and Deferred shares, leaving £5,002 to be carried forward. Coal Imports.— From the 1st January to the 19th April, the quantity of coal imported into Egypt was 910,629 tons,as against 385,598 tons in the same period of 1904. Newcastle it 49,895 tons, the Welsh districts 114,379, the scotch districts 96,051, Yorkshire 13,901, and Other districts 6,903 tons.

div.head: BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BREMEN.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

BULLETIN HEBDOMADAIRE
